For isolation of voltage-gated sodium currents (Figure 2H), internal KCl was replaced by CsCl to block potassium currents and 100 μM CdCl2 was used to block calcium currents.To examine the electrophysiological properties of identified individual motor neurons, we transduced developing neurons with an Hb9::RFP lentiviral reporter and recorded only from RFP-positive motor neurons (Marchetto et al., 2008) using whole-cell patch clamp
title: Intrinsic membrane hyperexcitability of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis patient-derived motor neurons.

text: Cell Survival and ER Stress Assays Dissociated neurons (20k) were plated on poly-D-lysine/laminin coated 8-well chamber slides (BD Biosciences) containing a confluent monolayer of primary cortical mouse glia (Boulting et al., 2011). For survival analysis, slides were fixed at 3 and 30 days, and cultures were stained for counting. The number of ISL-positive, TUJ1-positive motor neurons (counter blinded to cell line identity) was normalized to the number on day 3 for each line. Retigabine (1 μM) or vehicle control was added from day 15 onwards. 11 total experiments (control motor neurons) and nine total experiments (ALS motor neurons) were performed from the same four separate differentiations. ER stress experiments were performed as described in Kiskinis et al. In brief, in two separate independent biological replicates, 300 ng of RNA was used to generate cDNA, of which 2 μL and AmpliTaq Gold Polymerase (Applied Biosystems) were used for PCR amplification. The amounts of spliced and unspliced bands were quantified using Image J. Quantitative RT-PCR was performed in triplicate using the iSCRIPT kit (Biorad) for cDNA synthesis and SYBR green (Bio-Rad) labeling followed by amplification using the iCycler system (Bio-Rad).
title: Intrinsic membrane hyperexcitability of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis patient-derived motor neurons.

text: Assessment of Motor Function. Motor function was evaluated in human SOD1 G93A transgenic mice by a paw grip endurance (PaGE) test and rotarod test between day 133 and day 147, at which point transgenic mice display severe motor dysfunction. The PaGE test was conducted according to the procedure described by Weydt et al. (2003). Briefly, the mice were placed on the wired lid of the cage until they firmly grabbed the wire. Then, gently, the lid was flipped upside down and the time until the mouse let go with at least both hind limbs was recorded. Twenty seconds were chosen as the arbitrary cutoff time. For the rotarod test, mice were placed on a rod (3 cm in diameter) and evaluated for their motor performance by rotating the rod at the speed of 7 rpm. One hundred twenty seconds were chosen as the arbitrary cutoff time. In both tests, each mouse was given at least three trials and the best record was chosen.
title: Effect of rosmarinic acid in motor dysfunction and life span in a mouse model of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: Clinical Scoring. Between day 133 (19 weeks old) and day 147 (21 weeks old), a behavioral test was performed for all animals in randomized order by an observer blinded to the genotype (Weydt et al., 2003). The mice were evaluated for signs of motor deficit with the following five criteria: 4 points if normal, 3 points if hind limb tremors are evident when suspended by the tail, 2 points if gait abnormalities are present, 1 point for dragging of at least one hind limb, 0 point for inability to right itself within 30 sec.
title: Effect of rosmarinic acid in motor dysfunction and life span in a mouse model of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text:
Histological Analysis. Lumbar spinal cord samples were obtained from transgenic mice at day 154, when they already showed symptoms of severe motor deficiency. After fixation by 10% neutralized formalin, 10-lm-thick sections were prepared and stained with Kluver-Barrera staining to visualize the neuronal cells.

Both rosemary extract and RA were found to attenuate the degeneration of motor neurons in histological analysis
title: Effect of rosmarinic acid in motor dysfunction and life span in a mouse model of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: Immunoblotting. The primary antibodies were rabbit polyclonal IgG against active form of STAT3 phosphorylated at amino acid residueY705 (p-STAT3) (Cat. No. 9131; Cell Signaling Technology, Danvers, MA, USA; diluted 1:2000), rabbit polyclonal IgG against STAT3 (Cat. No. 9132; Cell Signaling; diluted 1:2000), and mouse monoclonal IgG1 against b-actin (Clone No.AC-15; Sigma Chemical, St. Lous, MO, USA; diluted 1:10 000). The data sheets confirmed the specificity of the anti-STAT3 antibody with both phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated forms of STAT3. Freshly frozen materials of each spinal cord were used for obtaining nuclear and cytoplasmic protein extracts, using the NE-PERTM kit (Pierce, Rockford, IL, USA) containing the protease inhibitor cocktail Complete Mini® (Roche Diagnostics, Manheim, Germany). Protein concentration in tissue samples was measured by the Bradford method.14 Samples were boiled for 10 min at 100°C with equal volumes of Laemli’s buffer in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.5 (TBS). Aliquots of the samples (20 mg/Lane) were separated by 10% sodium-dodecyl sulfate (SDS)- polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and electroblotted onto a polyvinyliden difluoride (PVDF) membrane (Millipore, Tokyo, Japan). The PVDF membranes were treated for 1 h at room temperature with 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) inTBS containing 0.1%Tween-20 (TBS-T) and subsequently incubated with the anti-p-STAT3 antibody in Can Get Signal® (Toyobo,Tokyo, Japan) overnight at 4°C followed by horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-labeled donkey anti-rabbit IgG (GE Healthcare, Buckinghamshire, UK; diluted 1:10 000) in Can Get Signal for 1 h at room temperature. Immunoreaction was visualized by the chemi-illuminescence method using the ECL-plus kit (GE). After eluting with stripping solution consisting of TBS and 1% mercaptoethanol, blots were treated for 1 h at room temperature with 5% skim milk in TBS-T and incubated with the anti-STAT3 antibody in 5% skim milk in TBS-T overnight at 4°C followed by the HRP-labeled antirabbit IgG in 5% skim milk in TBS-T for 1 h at room temperature. Blots were then incubated with the anti-bactin antibody in 5% skim milk in TBS-T followed by HRP-labeled rabbit anti-mouse IgG (Dako, Glostrup, Denmark; diluted 1:2000) in 5% skim milk in TBS-T to detect immunoreaction with the ECL kit (GE). Blots from which the primary antibodies were omitted served as negative reaction controls. Immunoreactive signals for p-STAT3, STAT3 and b-actin on blots were scanned using the Light-Capture Cooled Camera System® (ATTO, Tokyo, Japan) and imported into a personal computer. Opitical densities of these signals were measured using the CS Analyzer® image software (ATTO).
title: Activation of STAT3 and inhibitory effects of pioglitazone on STAT3 activity in a mouse model of SOD1-mutated amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
journal: Neuropathology : official journal of the Japanese Society of Neuropathology

text: Immunohistochemistry. The primary antibodies were mouse monoclonal IgG1 against dephosphorylated neurofilament protein (dp-NFP) (Clone No. SMI32; Sternberger Monoclonals, Baltimore, MD, USA; diluted 1:1000), goat polyclonal IgG against glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) (Cat. No. sc-6170; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA, US; diluted 1:300) and rabbit polyclonal IgG against the macrophage/ microglia-specific calcium-binding protein of 17 kDa Iba (Iba1) (Cat. No. 019-19741; Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Osaka, Japan; diluted 1:300) as well as the anti-p- STAT3 antibody (diluted 1:300) and the anti-STAT3 antibody (diluted 1:300). dp-NFP, GFAP and Iba1 were used as markers of neurons, astrocytes and microglia, respectively. Multiple 6-mm-thick sections cut from OCT compound-embedded, frozen materials of each spinal cord were air-dried, rehydrated, quenched for 10 min at 4°C in 3% H2O2, rinsed in phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.6 (PBS), pretreated for 20 min at room temperature with 3% skim milk in PBS, and then incubated overnight at 4°C with the primary antbodies. Immunoreaction was visualized by the polymer immunocomplex (PIC) method using the Envision system (Dako, Glostrup, Denmark) or the avidinbiotin- immunoperoxidase complex (ABC) method (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA, USA), according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The chromogen was 3,3′-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (DAB) or nickel dichloride/DAB mixture (NiCl2/DAB). Immunohistochemical localization of p-STAT3 and STAT3 was identified by the double-staining method with a light microscope.15 In brief, sections were incubated with the antibodies to the cell markers, and immunoreaction was detected by the PIC or ABC method using DAB as the chromogen. After microwaving (500 W, 95°C, 15 min) in citrate buffer, pH 6.0, sections were incubated with the antibodies to p-STAT3 and STAT3, and immunoreaction was detected by the PIC method using NiCl2/DAB as the choromogen.
title: Activation of STAT3 and inhibitory effects of pioglitazone on STAT3 activity in a mouse model of SOD1-mutated amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
journal: Neuropathology : official journal of the Japanese Society of Neuropathology

text: 2.1. Enzyme analysis. The effects of MSO treatment in vivo on GS activity in vitro were analyzed in brain tissue obtained fromSODG93A mice treatedwith either saline or MSO (20 mg/kg, 3×/wk – Monday, Wednesday, and Friday – for 3 weeks ) starting at 50 days of age (±2 days) and sacrificed at 70 days of age (±2 days). Brains were removed, homogenized, and GS activity determined according to the method of Meister [26], using glutamine and hydroxylamine as substrates, and measuring the concentration of the γ-glutamyl hydroxamate product by comparison to a standard curve of pure glutamyl hydroxamate (gift from Arthur J. Cooper, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, New York Medical College).The effect of this non-toxic, chronic MSO treatment on the neurochemical profile of GLU, GLN, GABA, GSH, and the GLN/GLU ratio was determined in discrete punches from the anterior dorsal striatum and motor cortex from SOD1G93A mice.
title: Methionine sulfoximine, an inhibitor of glutamine synthetase, lowers brain glutamine and glutamate in a mouse model of ALS.

text:
2.2. HR-MAS 1H-MRS analysis. Neurochemical profiles were determined in 2 groups (saline or MSO-treated, N=6 per group, equal gender) of SOD1G93A mice. MSO or saline (20 mg/kg IP) was administered thrice weekly for 3 weeks (on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday); treatment was initiated at postnatal day 50 (±2 days) and animals sacrificed at postnatal day 70 (±2 days). The present study focused on glutamine (GLN), glutamate (GLU), γ-amino butyric acid (GABA) and glutathione (GSH) levels in the dorsal anterior striatum (AST) and motor cortices. The motor cortex (MC) punch included primary somatosensory cortex, primary motor cortex, and secondary motor cortex (Fig. 1). Limitations of HR-MAS 1H-MRS include a dependence of proton visibility under MR conditions and sufficient concentrations (N0.5 mM); additionally, 1H-MRS measures do not differentiate extracellular or sub-cellular compartmentalization. After animals were sacrificed by decapitation, whole brains were immediately removed, placed in a chilled brain matrix (ASI, Warren, MI), and cut in 2 mmcoronal slices. Slices were immediately frozen on a solid CO2 then two contralateral, 1.5 mm (diameter) punches taken from the individual slices that contained the regions of interest [27]. Frozen punches were transferred to micro-centrifuge tubes and stored at −80 °C until HR-MAS 1H MRS or HPLC analysis. Frozen intact tissue samples were weighed (∼3 mg) and placed directly into a Bruker zirconium rotor (4mm diameter, 10 μL capacity) containing 5μL buffer (pH=7.4; 100 mM potassium phosphate, 200 mM formate, 1 g/L NaN3 and 3 mM trimethylsilyl-propionate [TSP Sigma; St Louis, MO] diluted with an equal volume of D2O containing 0.75% TSP). TSP serves as an internal chemical shift reference (0.00 ppm), formate (8.44 ppm) for phase corrections, and D2O to lock on the center frequency. The rotor (with sample)was placed into a Brukermagic angle spinning probemaintained at 4 °C in a verticalwidebore (8.9 cm) Bruker 11.7 T magnet with an AVANCETM DRX-500 spectrometer (Bruker Biospin Corp., Billerica, MA). Rotors were spun at 4.2±0.002 kHz at 54.7° relative to the static magnetic field B0. Field inhomogeneities were compensated using first and second order manual and semi-automated shimming. After a pre-saturation pulse for water suppression, tissue spectra were acquired with a rotor-synchronized 1-D Carr-Purcell-Meiboom-Gill (CPMG) [28] pulse sequence [90–(τ–180–τ)n–acquisition]. The inter-pulse delay (τ) was 150 μs and the 180° echo pulse was applied 12 times (n=12) for a total echo time TE=3.6 ms. The 90° pulse length was 6 μs, acquisition time=1.169 s, 16384 complex data points, TR=6.21 s, and a spectral band width of 7 kHz (14 ppm) was used. The number of transients (number of samplings) was 32 with total acquisition time of 3 min 48 s. Signals were acquired with Bruker-XWINNMR (v 3.6 software) and the identical brain region from all animals (n=12: 6 treated with saline, 6 treated with MSO) randomly analyzed in a single session by an operator blind to drug treatment. Spectra were analyzed with a custom LCModel software package version 6.1–4 [29], utilizing a linear combination of 27 individual neurochemical model spectra (basis set) as well as non-specific lipid signals to fit the tissue spectrum and calculate absolute concentration values for neurochemicals with signals between 1.0 and 4.2 ppm. The precision of the LCModel fit to the spectral data was estimated with Cramér–Rao bounds which were acceptable under 25% and typically less than 10% for most of the metabolites reported herein. To account for variations in the mass of individual samples, absolute concentrations of MRvisible metabolites were corrected for tissue weight and are expressed as nmol/mg of wet tissue weight; variance associated with means (see Results) suggests a substantial degree of analytical reproducibility. Representative spectra from SOD1G93A striata (±MSO pretreatment) are presented in Fig. 2. 

Levels of glutamine (GLN), glutamate (GLU), γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glutathione (GSH) in the motor cortex (MC) and dorsal anterior striatum (AST) were determined by HR-MAS 1H-MRS. ⁎Pb0.05 compared to saline-treated controls.
title: Methionine sulfoximine, an inhibitor of glutamine synthetase, lowers brain glutamine and glutamate in a mouse model of ALS.

text: 2.3. HPLC analysis. Parent monoamines andmetabolites were determined in individual punches by high pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) with electrochemical detection. Frozen tissue samples were weighed, sonically disrupted in 200 μL of 0.2 M HClO4, and centrifuged for 5 min to separate cellular debris. One hundred μL of clear supernatant was removed and placed into sample vials in an ESA 542 autoinjector (set at 4 °C). Ten μL were injected onto a C18-RP column (30 °C) with ESA MD-TM mobile phase running at a flow rate of 0.6 ml/min. Coulometric detection was accomplished with an ESA 5011A dual electrode cell (220mV) and the signal analyzed on an EZChrome Elite data processing platform. Absolute tissue values (ng/mg) for norepinephrine (NE), 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid (DOPAC), dopamine (DA), 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA), homovanillic acid (HVA) and serotonin (5HT) were calculated by comparison to external standard curves determined with each batch of tissue samples.
title: Methionine sulfoximine, an inhibitor of glutamine synthetase, lowers brain glutamine and glutamate in a mouse model of ALS.

text: 2.4. Survival analysis. Mice were injected with MSO (15 mice) or saline (15 mice), three times every week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday), starting at 50 days of age (±2) until they were euthanized. Mice were observed daily by the supervising veterinarians and laboratory-animal staff and were euthanized when either 1) they lost 20% of their maximum body weight, 2) they were unable to right themselves when put on their back or side, or 3) if, in the opinion of the supervising veterinarians, the mice were in distress or unable to obtain adequate food and water.
title: Methionine sulfoximine, an inhibitor of glutamine synthetase, lowers brain glutamine and glutamate in a mouse model of ALS.

text: Behavioral assessment analysis. Baseline behavioral measurements were carried out one week before starting the weekly intramuscular injections (at approximately 73 days of age). Neuromuscular function was then assessed bi-weekly thereafter; the day following the injections and every third day post-injection for six weeks, using four methods. The ALS motor score (7) and the BBB locomotor rating scale (33) were used to record the degree of ALS related motor disability and assess walking ability. An accelerating rotarod apparatus and an automated Grip Strength Meter (Columbus Instruments, Columbus, OH) were used to assess motor performance and hindlimb grip strength, respectively. The average of three test trials was computed for both behavioral assays. The accelerating rotarod test was performed beginning at 5 rpm and increasing by 0.1 rpm/s until the rat fell off. All observations were performed by an investigator blinded to the treatment protocol. Rats were also observed daily and weighed bi-weekly. Disease onset was defi ned by the fi rst day an ALS motor score of 4 was recorded. The changes in rotarod performance and grip strength were expressed as a percentage change from baseline.
title: Intramuscular administration of a VEGF zinc finger transcription factor activator (VEGF-ZFP-TF) improves functional outcomes in SOD1 rats.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Histological analysis and motor neuron quantification. One week after the last intramuscular injection (at 115 days of age), the rats were euthanized with an intraperitoneal overdose of pentobarbital, followed by transcardial perfusion with 0.9% saline and 4% paraformaldehyde solutions. The spinal cords were removed, cryoprotected overnight in 30% sucrose solution, and frozen in Optimal Cutting Temperature Compound (OCT). The potential neuroprotective effect of VEGF on motor neuron survival was assessed using published protocols (34,35). Briefl y, coronal spinal cord sections (30 μ m) in the lumbar region were cut on a crytostat and stained with Cresyl violet. Images were obtained using a Nikon DS-Fil color digital camera on a Nikon E400 microscope and quantifi ed using the NIS-Elements software (Nikon Instruments Inc., Melville, NY). Motor neurons in these areas (minimum 180- μ m interval; 14 – 18 sections/rat) were scored based on size, morphology, and neuronal vacuolization by an investigator blinded to the treatment group. Cells with a readily identifi able nucleus were manually outlined to determine the area. Mean area of MNs was used as an assay for the relative size of these cells, which are recognized to atrophy in the course of disease. All neurons with an area 300 μ m 2 were counted as motor neurons (36).
title: Intramuscular administration of a VEGF zinc finger transcription factor activator (VEGF-ZFP-TF) improves functional outcomes in SOD1 rats.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Neuromuscular junctions. The medial gastrocnemius muscle was isolated from the injected hindlimb and dissected prior to perfusion, fl ash frozen in dry ice-cooled isopentane, placed in a sucrose (30%) OCT (1:2) mixture and cut (50 μ m) using a cryostat. Sections were rinsed in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 0.01 M , pH 7.4), pre-blocked in a solution containing 0.3% Triton-X-100 and 2.5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in PBS at room temperature for 1 h. The sections were then incubated in rabbit anti-neuronal class III β -tubulin (1:1000; PRB-435P, Covance, Emeryville, CA) and rabbit anti-synaptophysin (1:100; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) antibodies overnight at 4 ° C. Subsequently, after several rinses in PBS, the sections were incubated in a solution containing anti-rabbit IgG conjugated to Alexa Fluoro 488 (1:500; Invitrogen) and rhodamine conjugated α -bungarotoxin (1:100; Invitrogen). Immunoreactive agents were diluted in PBS containing 2.5% BSA, and 0.3% Triton-X-100. Sections were rinsed in PBS (0.5 M , pH 7.6) before being mounted in a glycerol-PBS (1:1) mixture. Stained sections were examined under a fluorescence microscope. The percentage of innervated neuromuscular junctions was determined based on the colocalization of the presynaptic (tubulin and synaptophysin) and postsynaptic ( α -bungarotoxin) markers.
title: Intramuscular administration of a VEGF zinc finger transcription factor activator (VEGF-ZFP-TF) improves functional outcomes in SOD1 rats.

text: Muscle fiber composition. Sections from the medial gastrocnemius muscle were prepared as described above and incubated in primary antibodies against fast (1:500; Sigma) and slow (1:10; Iowa Developmental Hybridoma Bank) myosin fibers. Stained sections were examined under a fluorescence microscope to determine the percentage of fast and slow muscle fibers.
title: Intramuscular administration of a VEGF zinc finger transcription factor activator (VEGF-ZFP-TF) improves functional outcomes in SOD1 rats.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Behavioural assessment General condition. For weekly assessment of general condition from week 14 we used a behavioural score system as previously described (28), based on the score developed by Vercelli et al. (29) from 1 to 5 defi ned as follows: 5: healthy without any symptoms of paralysis; 4: slight signs of destabilized gait and paralysis of the hind limbs; 3: obvious paralysis and destabilized gait; 2: fully developed paralysis of the hind limbs, animals only crawl on the forelimbs; 1: fully developed paralysis of the hind limbs, animals predominantly lie on the side and/or are not able to straighten up after being turned on the back, or lost more than 20% of their starting weight. When animals reached a score of 2, macerated food was given daily for easy access to food and hydration. On reaching a score of 1, the animals were euthanized.
title: CDP-choline is not protective in the SOD1-G93A mouse model of ALS.

text: Evaluation of onset and survival. Day of onset was set as the fi rst day the animals reached a score of 4 in the daily behavioural assessment. Animals were euthanized when they reached a score of 1 and this age (in days) was recorded as survival time.
title: CDP-choline is not protective in the SOD1-G93A mouse model of ALS.

text: Weight. We recorded the weight of the animals weekly, beginning at 10 weeks of age, using a normal digital balance ranging up to 800 g in 0.1-g steps.
title: CDP-choline is not protective in the SOD1-G93A mouse model of ALS.

text: Footprint analyses. Footprint analyses for step length and runtime were performed weekly starting the same week as rotarod tests performance (28). The hind feet were dipped into black fi ngerprint and animals were placed on a gangway covered with conventional masking tape. Footprints were analysed with respect to the step length using the FOOTPRINTS software (Version 1.22 by K. Klapdor and B. Dulfer (30)). In addition, the time animals required to run along the track (50 cm) was measured.
title: CDP-choline is not protective in the SOD1-G93A mouse model of ALS.

text: Motor neuron survival . One slide per animal (i.e. 5 – 6 spinal cord sections) was rehydrated in xylene and graded ethanol, stained with 0.2% Thionin, dehydrated in graded ethanol and xylene and coverslipped with Eukitt quick hardening mounting medium (Sigma- Aldrich, Steinheim, Germany). At 20x magnifi - cation in an Olympus BX61 microscope, cells in the ventral horn region with a diameter 200 μ m ² were defi ned as motor neurons, according to Chen et al., who determined α -motor neurons as cells with cell body areas ranging from 200 to 1100 μ m ² (31), and counted, using cell * software (Olympus, Hamburg, Germany). Only intact ventral horn regions were used for counting so that, depending on the quality of the section, 5 – 12 ventral horn regions were counted for motor neuron numbers and the mean was used for statistical evaluation.
title: CDP-choline is not protective in the SOD1-G93A mouse model of ALS.

text:
Western Blotting. For classical estrogen receptors (ERa and ERb), immunodetection western blotting was performed in control (non-treated) rat spinal cord explants. For Akt immunodetection rat, spinal cord explants were pre-incubated for 4 h in the absence of serum and then exposed to 17bE2 (10 nM) at selected times from 30 min to 48 h. The ER antagonist ICI 182,780 (1 lM) was added, when indicated, 2 h before 17bE2 exposure. After treatments, explants were rinsed rapidly in ice-cold phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and lysed in 2 % sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), 125 mM Tris buffer, pH 6.8 containing the broad-spectrum phosphatase inhibitor a-naphthyl acid phosphate (Calbiochem, Darmstadt, Germany) and a cocktail of protease inhibitors (Complete Mini; Roche Pharmaceuticals, Basel, Switzerland). Lysates were sonicated and proteins quantified by means of the DC Protein Assay from Bio-Rad Laboratories (Hercules, CA, USA). Protein equivalents from each sample were resolved in SDS–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and electrotransferred to 0.45-lm nitrocellulose membranes (Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK) using a Bio-Rad semidry Trans-Blot, according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Membranes were blocked at 21 ± 1 C for 1 h with TBS containing 5 % non-fat dry milk, 0.5 % bovine serum albumin and 0.2 % Tween 20. Membranes were probed overnight at 4 C with the adequate primary antibodies: anti-ERa (1:500), anti-ERb (1:1,000) (both also employed for immunofluorescence, see below) and antiphospho- Akt (P-Akt) (Ser473) (1:1000; Cat. #9271) or anti-Akt (1:1000; Cat. #9272) from Cell Signaling Technology. Membranes were then washed with Tris buffer saline (TBS) for 10 min at 21 ± 1 C (three times) and incubated for 2 h with the appropriate peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies. Blots were finally developed with the chemiluminiscent peroxidase substrate and visualized in chemiluminiscence film (Amersham). The apparent molecular weight of proteins was determined by calibrating the blots with pre-stained molecular weight markers (Bio-Rad).

The expression of classical estrogen receptors (ERa and ERb) in rat spinal cord embryonic explants was first studied by western blotting in order to test the specificity of the two commercial antisera.Extracts (10 lg of protein) were prepared and analyzed by western blotting using anti-phosphospecific Akt (P-Akt) antibody or anti-Akt as a control of the total amount of the specific protein loaded per lane

title: Neuroprotective effects of estradiol on motoneurons in a model of rat spinal cord embryonic explants.

text:
Immunofluorescence. The following primary antibodies were used for immunofluorescence: anti-neurofilament heavy chain (SMI-32; 1:1000; Cat. #ab73273) and anti-ERb (1:500; Cat. #ab3577) from Abcam plc (Cambridge, UK); anti-glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) (1:1000; Cat. #MAB 360) from Chemicon (Billerica, MA, USA); anti-ERa (1:1000; Cat. #06-935) from Upstate (Temecula, CA, USA); anti-P-Akt (Ser473) (1:250; Cat. #4058) and anti-phospho-glycogen synthase kinase 3-b (P-GSK-3b) (Ser9) (1:100; Cat. #9323) from Cell Signaling Technology (Danvers, MA, USA) and anti-Bcl-2 (1:500; Cat. #PAB18269) from Abnova (Taipei City, Taiwan). For lectin cytochemistry, the lectin from Lycopersicon esculentum (tomato lectin) labeled with fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) (25 lg/ml) was used. For P-Akt and P-GSK-3b, immunofluorescence cultures were pre-incubated for 4 h in the absence of serum and then for 2 (P-Akt) or 4 h (P-GSK-3b) in the presence of 17bE2 (10 nM). For Bcl-2 immunofluorescence cultures were treated for 72 h in the presence of 17bE2 (10 nM). The ER antagonist ICI 182,780 (1 lM) was added, when indicated, 2 h before 17bE2 exposure. After treatments, rat spinal cord explants were fixed with 4 % paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 for 20 min at 21 ± 1 C. Explants were washed three times with TBS, pH 7.6 and then blocked in 0.1 % Triton X-100, 5 % normal horse serum in TBS for 1 h. Explants were then incubated overnight at 4 C with one or two of the above primary antibodies. Immunofluorescence controls, performed by omitting the primary antibody, resulted in the abolition of the immunostaining. Sections were then incubated for 1 h with the appropriate secondary antibody: Alexa Fluor 555 goat anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG (1:200), Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-mouse or anti-rabbit IgG (1:200) (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). Cultures were then washed and mounted using fluorescent mounting media (DAKO). Images were obtained with a Leica TCS SP2 confocal laser-scanning microscope. Images for the different experimental treatments were taken with similar conditions (laser intensities and photomultiplier voltages). The immunofluorescence of all the migrated motoneurons encountered in a well was quantified, with at least three wells for experimental condition. Quantitative analysis of the fluorescently labeled structures was performed in a blinded manner with ImageJ (W. Rasband, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD; http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/). 

To assess if the phosphorylation of Akt could also be detected specifically inImmunofluorescence after stimulation with 17bE2 (2h), immunofluorescence co-localization experiments were performed and showed the presence of phosphorylated Akt in these cells
title: Neuroprotective effects of estradiol on motoneurons in a model of rat spinal cord embryonic explants.

text: Quantification of Apoptotic Motoneuron Death. Where indicated, rat spinal cord explants were exposed for 48 h to a combination of the cytokines TNF-a (10 ng/ml) and IFN-c (10 ng/ml). Explants receiving cytokines and 17bE2 (10 nM) were treated with estrogen 24 h prior to cytokines exposure. The ER antagonist ICI 182,780 (1 lM) was added, when indicated 2 h before 17bE2 exposure. Lysates from these explants were also processed for P-Akt and Akt immunodetection as previously described. The time of exposure and the concentration of the cytokines TNF-a and IFN-c were chosen based on our previous work demonstrating apoptotic motoneuron death under these conditions (Mir et al. 2009). The concentrations of 17bE2 and ICI 182,780 were chosen based on previous studies showing neuroprotective effects of 17bE2 (Honda et al. 2000). To assess whether the above treatments affected the viability of motoneurons, their ability to induce apoptotic cell death was monitored by means of the APOAC Annexin V-Cy3 apoptosis detection kit (Sigma-Aldrich) as previously described (Mir et al. 2009); this kit detects the presence of phosphatidylserine residues on the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane by means of the protein annexin conjugated to the fluorochrome Cy3.18 (Koopman et al. 1994). Briefly, explants were rinsed with PBS, pH 7.4 at 37 C for 10 min, and then exposed to annexin V-Cy3 (1 lg/ ml) in the binding buffer supplied by the manufacturer. Then, explants were rinsed again with PBS and processed for SMI-32 immunofluorescence. The percentage of motoneurons undergoing apoptotic cell death was assessed by counting the number of annexin V-Cy3 positive cells that could be identified as motoneurons both by morphological and immunocytochemical criteria (i.e., doublelabeled with annexin V-Cy3 and SMI-32), relative to the total number of motoneurons (SMI-32 positive) in the whole area of the well. Only motoneurons with their somata out of the explant were counted. Cell counts were done blindly as to the treatment condition and at least three different wells were counted for each experimental condition.
title: Neuroprotective effects of estradiol on motoneurons in a model of rat spinal cord embryonic explants.

text: Motor Function Testing (Rotarod). An accelerating rotarod device (Columbus Instruments, Columbus, OH) was used to test motor function. At 9 weeks of age, mice were trained for 2 days to become acquainted with the rotarod; in the training sessions, a fixed-speed protocol (20 rpm) with a cutoff of 120 sec was applied. At 70 days of age, a ramped accelerating program (the rod was accelerated at a constant rate from 8 rpm to 32 rpm for a maximum of 180 sec) was started. Mice were given three consecutive trials (10-min intervals), and for each animal the longest latency to fall was recorded as a measure of the motor function competence. Rotarod testing was performed once per week until the animals reached the pre-established minimum performance (5 sec).
title: Effects of chronic caffeine intake in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: Determination of Body Weigth, Disease Onset, and Survival. Body weight was recorded for each animal three times per week (from 9 AM to 12 AM to avoid diurnal variations). Disease onset was defined as the time at which a 10% decline in the mouse rotarod performance was observed. The survival time was considered as the actual age of death or the time when mice were sacrificed because they had lost the ability to right themselves within 30 sec after having been placed on their sides according to established guidelines for drug testing in ALS mouse models (Ludolph et al., 2010). In order to proceed to euthanasia (primary end-point), the 30 sec/side righting test was performed by a researcher who was blinded to the treatment group. Wild-type animals were sacrificed when the last transgenic mouse died.
title: Effects of chronic caffeine intake in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text:
Western Blot Analysis. At the time of sacrifice, the spinal column containing the vertebrae and the spinal cord was immediately removed. The whole spinal cords were extracted from the spinal canal using a 20-ml syringe, filled with saline phosphate buffer and connected to a 21-gauge 1.5-inch-long needle; the needle was inserted into the caudal opening of the spinal canal, and, by applying pressure with the syringe piston, the spinal cord was flushed out of the rostral opening into a Petri dish containing phosphate buffer. The spinal cord was immediately stored at 2808C. For Western blot analysis, we used the whole spinal cord, because in end-stage animals the neuropathological changes affect the entire spinal cord (Yang et al., 2011). Tissues were processed as described by Danbolt et al. (1990) to generate a membrane-enriched pellet. The pellet was resuspended in 50 mM Tris, pH 7.4, and 1 mM EDTA and stored at 2808C. The supernatant, containing cytosolic proteins, was stored at 2808C. Proteins were separated on 8% acrylamide gels and electroblotted onto polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membranes (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA). Membranes were blocked with 5% nonfat dry milk in TBST buffer (0.1 M Tris base, 0.15 M NaCl, 0.05% Tween 20, pH 7.4) and then incubated with anti-A2A (1:1,00; Upstate Biotechnology, Lake Placid, NY), anti-GLT1 (1:8,000; Chemicon, Temecula, CA), anti-GFAP (1:5,000; Chemicon) and anti-b-tubulin (1:20,000; Chemicon) antibodies. After incubation with horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-linked antibody (1:5,000), visualization of the bound antibodies was performed with the ECL system (Pierce, Rockford, IL). Densitometric analyses were perfomed in ImageJ 1.64. 

The expression of adenosine A2A receptors (A2ARs), glial glutamate transporter (GLT1), and glial fibrillar acidic protein (GFAP) were evaluated by Western blotting. The results showed that caffeine intake significantly shortened the survival of SOD1G93A mice (log rank test, P 5 0.01) and induced a nonsignificant advancing of disease onset.
title: Effects of chronic caffeine intake in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: 2.1. Clinical evaluation of symptoms. Behavioral experiments were conducted in a single-blind manner. Clinical status of all ALSmicewas evaluated three times perweek beginning 60 days after birth. Symptom onset was defined to be a mouse's limbs shaking when suspended in the air by its tail, which was suggested to be due to the clinical involvement of the upper motor neuron system[7,9]. Clonus, hyperreflexia, and crossed spread of spinal reflexes were also detected in most mice at disease onset. Disease endpointwas defined to be when a mouse was unable to stand upright within 30 s after being placed on their sides on a flat surface. At this point, the mice were killed [7,9]. Mice were subjected to a 1-week long learning period 53 days after birth, duringwhich they performed an accelerating rotarod test. The rotarod test was performed 3 days per week. The time spentwalking on the rotarod testwasmeasured, and timewas averaged over 3 days. If the mean time was less than 10 s, it was defined to be a rotarod failure.
title: Neuroprotective effects of JGK-263 in transgenic SOD1-G93A mice of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text:
2.2. Motor neuron cell count and western blotting for lumbar spinal cords. Choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) which is a well-known marker for cholinergic motor neurons staining was used to count motor neuron cells. Animals were sacrificed at different time-points (90 days and 110 days) depending on the clinical features of the G93A transgenic mice of ALS. Mice from each group were terminally euthanized with pentobarbital sodium and then perfused transcardially with cold PBS followed by cold paraformaldehyde. Lumbar spinal cords were dissected, fixed in paraformaldehyde, and cryoprotected in a cold sucrose solution. Dissection was performed carefully preserving the anatomical integrity of the spinal cord tissue and 12-μm-thick transverse sections were obtained. Motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord were stained for choline acetyltransferase (anti-ChAT; Millipore, Billerica, MA, USA) and were counted, as previously described [9,22]. Motor neuron cells stained in the anterior horn of the lumbar spinal cord were counted. To evaluate the possible mechanisms of JGK-263 in the transgenic ALS mice model, western blotting of PI3K p85 and phospho-Akt, phospho-GSK-3β, and antibodies of apoptosis signals was performed. Forwestern blotting, micewere anesthetizedwith pentobarbital sodium, and intracardiac perfusion of PBS was carried out. Shortly after, the spinal cord of each mouse was quickly removed, cooled in ice-cold artificial cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) for 5 min, and stored at−80 °C. Each spinal cord was homogenized with a 1.0 ml homogenizer and type B pestle in a 10:1 volume/weight buffer containing 10mMTris (pH 7.4), 10mMEGTA, 250mMsucrose, 2 μg/ml aprotinin, 5 μg/ml leupeptin, 2 μg/ml pepstatin, and 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF). Tissue lysates were centrifuged at 17,000 ×g for 10 min, and supernatants were used to measure phospho-GSK-3β (Cell Signaling Tech, Beverly, MA, USA), Caspase 3 (Cell Signaling Tech, Beverly, MA, USA), cytochrome C (Cell Signaling Tech, Beverly, MA, USA), PARP-1(Santa Cruz Biotech, Delaware, CA, USA), PI3K p85 (Santa Cruz Biotech, Delaware, CA, USA), and phosphor-Akt (Santa Cruz Biotech, Delaware, CA, USA) levels. Protein loading was controlled by probing for b-actin (Cell signaling, Beverly,MA, USA) antibody on the same membrane.

Western blot analysis showed decreased levels of cytochrome C (cytosol form), cleaved caspase-3, and cleaved PARP-1 in the spinal cords of 110-day-old G93A transgenic ALS mice treated with JGK-263 compared to control mice
title: Neuroprotective effects of JGK-263 in transgenic SOD1-G93A mice of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: Proteasome activation. The test was conducted using a proteasome activity assay kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Abcam, Cambridge, UK). Lysates of the INS-1E cells were used as a source of the proteasome.[ 39]
title: A chemical chaperone-based drug candidate is effective in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

text: Measurement of mice neurological functions. As disease progresses, SOD1 mice gradually begin to lose their ability to extend their legs. From day 90 the mice were evaluated weekly for their hind-limb reflex by a blinded observation. Each mice was given the following score: 0 for full extension of both hind limbs, 1 for extension of the legs of no more than 50% of the capacity, and 2 for no extension in both hind limbs.
title: A chemical chaperone-based drug candidate is effective in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

text: 2.3. Assessment of clinical symptoms. Forelimb deformity was graded as 1, paw atrophy; 2, curled digits; 3, curled wrists; and 4, forelimb flexion to chest. Forelimb strength of forelimbs wasmeasured as described previously [11–15]. These assessments were performed weekly from the beginning (pre-treatment) to the end of treatment in a blinded fashion.
title: Neuroprotective effect of ultra-high dose methylcobalamin in wobbler mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: 2.4. Morphometry of bicep muscle and musculocutaneous nerve. After treatment, wobbler mice (n = 10/group) were anesthetized with ether and intraperitoneal injection of pentobarbital sodium (40mg/kg), and the right bicep muscleswere removed under a dissectingmicroscope. Theywere accurately weighed and frozen. Serial 10 μm sections were stained with NADH. The mean diameter of muscle fibers was determined. Morphometric analysis was also done in five agematched healthy littermates for comparison. After dissection of the right bicep muscles, the left musculocutaneous nerve at the bicep muscle insertion (the motor nerve for the bicep muscle) was sampled under a dissecting microscope. Transverse sections, 0.5 μm thick, were prepared from the musculocutaneous nerves. The total number and size of myelinated fibers in the musculocutaneous nerve were determined in three experimental groups and age-matched normal mice (n = 5), using morphometric system, MacScope®.
title: Neuroprotective effect of ultra-high dose methylcobalamin in wobbler mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

text: Evaluation of Movement Behavior. Throughout the study, the movement behavior of the rats in both experiments was measured twice a week by using an Ugo Basile 7650 accelerating rotarod (20 rpm) that automatically recorded the time that the rats could stay on the rotarod (Linton Instruments, UK). Rotarod pretraining for 10 days was performed before the implantation in order to obtain a baseline for rotarod performance. At the end of the training period all rats remained at least 180 s on the rotarod. Starting from the second day after the implantation or the osmotic pump replacement, the motor performance of the rats was measured in a blinded manner. The time that each rat remained on the rotarod was recorded (latency to fall). The maximum latency was arbitrarily set to 180 s. Each test was repeated 3 times, and the longest time spent on the rotarod data/ results was used for the statistical analysis. For the experiments described in figure 4b, the group of 6 naïve rats served as a standard. This group was also pretrained for 10 days and tested twice each week for a period of about 2 months.
title: Combined Treatment of an Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Rat Model with Recombinant GOT1 and Oxaloacetic Acid: A Novel Neuroprotective Treatment.

text: Assessment of Life Span. The time of death was set to be the time in which the animal was unable to right itself by 30 s after being placed on its back.
title: Combined Treatment of an Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Rat Model with Recombinant GOT1 and Oxaloacetic Acid: A Novel Neuroprotective Treatment.

text: Histology. The animals were anesthetized and perfused transcardially with cold phosphate-buffered saline followed by cold 4% paraformaldehyde. Each spinal cord and the associated nerve roots were dissected en bloc, fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight and processed for paraffin embedding. Twenty serial sections at the levels L1–L5 (6 μm thick) from each spinal cord were stained with Nissl and the modified Bielschowsky methods [32] and examined using a Nikon Eclipse E800 microscope with an attached Nikon DMX 1200 digital camera. ImagePro Plus software (Media Cybernetics, Silver Spring, Md., USA) was used for quantitative analysis. Five sections in each series were used for histological analysis after each staining. Motor neurons were defined as cells present within the gray matter, ventral to the central canal and having a cell body >25 μm in diameter. All sections were collected at the same level across animals. The number of neurons per 100 mm 2 was calculated in 10 microscopic fields of each sample (objective magnification 40×). A total of 70–100 motor neurons were measured for each spinal cord specimen. Only motor neurons having a distinct nucleus were counted, and their area was measured using ImagePro Plus software. All morphometric analyses were performed in a blinded manner. Data are presented as the mean ± SE of the number of motor neurons per group.
title: Combined Treatment of an Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Rat Model with Recombinant GOT1 and Oxaloacetic Acid: A Novel Neuroprotective Treatment.

text:
Locomotor activity assay. The locomotor activity of the adult flies was measured in a dark room using a countercurrent apparatus as described (Benzer, 1967). Groups of 50 flies (25 males and 25 females) after 30°C induction for 12∼14 days were given 15 s to move toward a white light source. They were then tapped down and moved to the next tube of the apparatus. After five runs, the distributions of the flies was measured, with the most active flies running into the most distal tube receiving a score of five and the least active flies staying in the original start tube receiving a score of zero. All the scores were then normalized against the average score of the control flies without rapamycin treatment.

We counted remaining flies every day for lifespan study and performed locomotor activity assays after 12- 14 days of dTDP overexpression under 30°C.
title: Rapamycin alleviates pathogenesis of a new Drosophila model of ALS-TDP.

text: Western blotting. For analysis of dTDP overexpression at higher temperature, the heads and thoraces from 15 males were collected on day 5 after 30°C induction. For analysis of p62 and dTDP expression levels, after 29°C induction for 14 days, the dTDP overexpression  from 15 males treated with rapamycin were collected. All samples were lysed in cold RIPA buffer (0.1% SDS, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.9) containing protease and phosphatase inhibitors (1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mM NaF, 1 mM sodium orthovanadate, and a mixture of protease inhibitors, Roche), and then sonicated. Extracts were cleared by centrifugation and were run on 8% or 10% polyacrylamide gels and transferred to PVDF membranes. Primary antibodies included rabbit anti-dTDP 1:2000 (Lin et al., 2011), rabbit anti-p62 1:2500 (Pircs et al., 2012), and mouse anti-tubulin (1:10000, Millipore). After hybridizations, blots were incubated at room temperature with the appropriate secondary antibodies and WesternBright™ ECL (Advansta).Western blotting analysis of expression levels of p62 and dTDP in the heads and thoraces of male adult flies were examined.
title: Rapamycin alleviates pathogenesis of a new Drosophila model of ALS-TDP.

text: Immunostaining. For the analysis of dTDP expression, the thoracic ganglia of male adults at 29°C for 13∼14 days were dissected in PBS, fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS with 0.25% Triton-X-100, and then irradiated using a microwave oven (Pelco BioWave, Pelco International). After blocking with 10% normal goat serum at room temperature for 1 h, the tissues were incubated overnight at room temperature with rabbit anti-dTDP (1:200). After washing, the tissues were incubated overnight at room temperature with biotinylated anti-rabbit antibody at 1: 250 (Molecular Probes) and rat anti-ELAV antibody at 1:200 dilution (Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank). They were then washed and incubated overnight with streptavidin- Alexa-546 antibody (1:1000; Molecular Probes) and Alexa-488 conjugated goat anti-rat antibody diluted 1:200 (Molecular Probes), respectively. For neuron counting, the primary antibodies used were rabbit anti-HB9 antibody at 1:1000 dilution (Lacin et al., 2014) and rat anti-ELAV antibody at 1:200 dilution, followed by Alexa-555 conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibody diluted at 1:200 (Molecular Probes) and Alexa-488 conjugated goat anti-rat antibody diluted at 1:200, respectively. The confocal images were acquired using Zeiss LSM710. ELAV and HB9-positive cells in the regions bordering T1 and T2 were counted using Imaris (Bitplane) and ImageJ (National Institutes of Health) software, respectively. Average cell counts were compared by the t-test, and significant differences were set at p < 0.05.

title: Rapamycin alleviates pathogenesis of a new Drosophila model of ALS-TDP.

text:
Preparation of hASC Extract. Subcutaneous adipose tissue was acquired from a normal human who provided written informed consent to participate in this study and was approved by the Institutional Review Board in Seoul National University Hospital. The preparation of extracts from human ASC has been described in our previous report [22]. Briefly, hASCs were harvested in cold PBS with a cell scraper and centrifuged at 2009g for 5 min. The cell pellets was suspended in 1 mL PBS and lysed by three cycles of rapidly freezing and thawing. The lysate was then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm for 15 min, and the protein content of the supernatant was quantified using a Bio-Rad protein assay kit (Bio-Rad Lab, Milan, Italy). Neurospheres were cultured in DMEM/F12, 1 % PSA, 2 % B27, and 5 % FBS for 6 days and cells were treated with 100 lg/ml hASC extract for 48 h.

These results demonstrate that hASC extract improve mitochondrial dysfunction in vitro test.
title: Neuroprotective Effect of Human Adipose Stem Cell-Derived Extract in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Clinical Evaluation of Symptoms. Rotarod testing was performed to evaluate motor function in mice [27, 28]. The rotarod test was performed three times per week beginning at PND 55. The time spent walking on the rotarod test was measured, and time was averaged over 3 days. If the mean time was less than 10 s, it was defined to be a rotarod failure. Symptom onset was defined to be the mouse’s limbs shaking when suspended in the air by its tail, which has been suggested to be due to the clinical involvement of the upper motor neurons [29]. Disease end point was defined as the time when a mouse was unable to stand upright within 30 s after being placed on its side on a flat surface. At this point, the mice were euthanized [30, 31].
title: Neuroprotective Effect of Human Adipose Stem Cell-Derived Extract in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text:
Protein Extraction and Western Blot Analysis. The spinal cord from G93A transgenic mice were isolated, immediately frozen in a deep freezer (-80 C), as previously described [34]. Cells cultured in a 6-well plate were washed and harvested in PBS using a cell scraper. Protein extracts were isolated by RIPA buffer (Thermo, MA, USA) with protease inhibitors and phosphatase inhibitors added to the buffer (Roche, IN, USA). Each 30 lg protein sample was loaded run on an SDS-PAGE gel and transferred onto a PVDF membrane. The blots were probed with primary antibodies for the following: b-actin (1:5000; Sigma, MO, USA), a-tubulin (1:2000; Santa Cruz, CA, USA), CREB (1:1000; Cell signaling, MA, USA), p-CREB (1:1000; Cell signaling), PGC-1a (1:1000; Santa Cruz), p-Akt (1:1000; Cell Signaling), Akt (1:1000; Cell Signaling), cleaved caspase-3 (1:1000; Cell Signaling), p53 (1:1000; Santa Cruz), Bax (1:1000; Santa Cruz), Bcl-2 (1:1000; Santa Cruz), cytochrome c (1:1000; Cell Signaling), BDNF (1:200; Santa Cruz), FGF-2 (1:200; Santa Cruz), HGF-a (1:200; Santa Cruz), PDGF-1 (1:200; Santa Cruz), IGF-1 (1:5000; Abcam Inc., MA, USA), and VEGF (1:5000; Abcam Inc.). Next, the blots were treated with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies (anti-mouse, rabbit or goat, 1:5000; GE Healthcare), and blots were developed using a chemiluminescent kit (Thermo). Protein loading was controlled by probing for b-actin or a-tubulin on the same membrane. The densitometry of protein intensity was performed by an image analyzer (LAS-3000; Fuji, Tokyo, Japan).

Western blot analysis confirmed that upregulation of the CREB-PGC-1a pathway in hASC extract-treated ALS mice lumbar spinal cord
title: Neuroprotective Effect of Human Adipose Stem Cell-Derived Extract in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text:
Rotarod Test. Motor coordination, strength and balance before and after genistein administration were assessed by the rotarod test. A rod rotating at 14 rpm were used to trained all animals three times a week. Test was performed in animals from 8 to 16 weeks of age. Presence of arbitrary maximum time of maintenance in the rotating rod of 180 s was defined as symptom free and the first day that the animal was unable to complete the 180 s on the rotating was defined as the time of clinical disease onset.

Rotarod test, hanging wire test and hindlimb clasping test were used to determined disease onset and assess motor performance.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Genistein in a SOD1-G93A Transgenic Mouse Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text:
Hanging Wire Test. Conventional cage wire lid was hanged 50 cm above a padding and was turned upside down after each animal was placed on the lid. The overall duration of observation was 60s. The latency time to fall was recorded as the duration that the mouse could hold on to the wire.

Rotarod test, hanging wire test and hindlimb clasping test were used to determined disease onset and assess motor performance.

text:
Hindlimb Clasping Test. Hindlimb clasping was assessed based on a previously reported method. The base of the tail was used to suspend the animal. Each animal was videotaped for 15 s. A scale of 0 to 3 based on severity was used to rate hindlimb clasping behavior: 0 = hindlimbs abducted away from the abdomen; 1 = one hindlimb adducted for at least 50% of the observation period; 2 = both hindlimbs partially adducted for at least 50% of the observation period; and 3 = both hindlimbs completely adducted for at least 50% of the observation period. Rate of 0.5, 1.5 or 2.5 was used when the performance of the mouse fell between two levels. Rates from three separate trials over three consecutive days was used to abstain an average.

Rotarod test, hanging wire test and hindlimb clasping test were used to determined disease onset and assess motor performance.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Genistein in a SOD1-G93A Transgenic Mouse Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Immunohistochemistry. Avertin was used to anesthetize the animals and ice-cold phosphate- buffered saline containing heparin (10 U/mL) was transcardially perfused before the animals were sacrificed. The lumbar spinal cords were collected and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde solution at 4 °C for 24 h before being processed for frozen sections every 40 μm.Primary antibodieswere anti- Iba-1 antibody (1:100, GeneTex, GTX101495), anti-GFAP antibody (1:100, CST, 3670S) and anti-NeuN antibody (1:100, Abcam, ab190195). Secondary antibodies were horse radish peroxidase (HRP)-labeled. All immunostained sections were then visualized with diaminobenzidine. In the meantime, Nissl detection kit (DK0022, solarbio) were used to detect motor neurons, according to the manufacturer’s protocol. An Olympus IX73 inverted microscope with DP80 camera was to attain all images. Motor neurons (MN) were identified and counted following strict size and morphological criteria: First, it should with diameters larger than 20 μm. Second, it should be with polygonal shape and prominent nucleoli. Only MNswith these characteristics werecounted (Dutta et al. 2018; Mancuso et al. 2011). For each animal, three fields of view per section were imaged and at least three sections were analyzed. All images were then analyzed by personnel who were blind to the genotype and treatment of the mice. Image J (National Institutes of Health, USA) was used to quantify the intensity of antibody labeling.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Genistein in a SOD1-G93A Transgenic Mouse Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text:
Western Blot. Radioimmunoprecipitation buffer with complete protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Diagnostics, Penzberg,Upper Bavaria, Germany) was used to homogenize the spinal cord tissues. Lysate was centrifuged at 16,000 g for 15 min at 4 °C. The supernatants were collected and the bicinchoninic acid protein assay (Pierce, Waltham, MA) was used to determine the protein concentration. A 4–12% sodium dodecyl sulfate– polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis gel (Invitrogen, Waltham, MA USA) was used to separate proteins that was subsequently transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane (Merck Millipore). The primary antibodies were anti-TLR2 (1:1000, Abcam, ab9100), anti-TLR4 (1:500, Santa Cruz, SC-13591), anti-p65 (1:500, Santa Cruz, SC-7151), anticox2 (1:100, GeneTex, GTX101495), anti-LC3b1 and LC3b2 (1:1000, Thermo Fisher Scientific PA5–32254), anti- GFAP (1:100, CST, 3670S), and anti-GAPDH (1:1000, CST, 2118S). All appropriate secondary antibodies were HRP-conjugated. Bands were attained by enhanced chemiluminescence (Pierce) and quantified by Image J.

Downregulation of P62 was detected by western blot, which indicated autophagic flux.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Genistein in a SOD1-G93A Transgenic Mouse Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.
