text: Determination of Clinical Parameters. The clinical progression of mice was evaluated weekly by measuring forelimb deformity, rotarod performance and body weight.Forelimb atrophy in the Wobbler group was graded as follows: (1) atrophy of forelimbs, (2) flexion of digits, (3) flexion of wrist, and (4) flexion of forelimb over the chest [34]. Visual inspection of changes was carried out weekly from the beginning until the end of treatment, and expressed as the deformity ratio of forelimbs between days of assessment over the first evaluation day. The rotarod test was employed to evaluate motor performance (Rotarod apparatus Model 755 Stoelting, IL, USA). Mice were placed on an accelerating rod (1 to 40 rpm) over a period of 180 s in order to determine the ability of the mouse to maintain on a rod that turns at accelerating speeds. Animals were pretrained every day during 1 week before treatment and were evaluated during eight weeks after treatment. We recorded the rate of acceleration (rpm) at which animals fell down and the length of time they could remain rotating. Each animal was evaluated three times and the average performance was used for animal comparisons. Rotarod performance was shown as the latency of time to fall (seconds). Thirteen to fifteen mice in each experimental group were evaluated weekly at the level of paw atrophy and rotarod performance.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Hormone Measurements. For steroid measurements, 53 mice were used (control, n = 16; control + testosterone, n = 12; Wobbler, n = 13; Wobbler + testosterone, n = 12). Sixty days after insertion of the implants, mice were euthanized by decapitation in the time range 10.00 AM–12.00 PM to avoid circadian effects. As anesthetics and stress can influence steroid levels, mice were handled gently to minimize stress and were quickly euthanized without anesthesia. Cervical spinal cords were dissected and frozen over dry ice and stored at − 80 °C until analysis. Samples from 2 different mice were randomly pooled to obtain sufficient amount of tissue, i.e., at least 40 to 50 mg, to detect with high precision the targeted steroids with a suitable signal-to-noise ratio. Levels of testosterone and its derivatives in cervical spinal cord were determined by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GCMS) [35]. Data (mean± SEM) were expressed as ng/g. Trunk blood of control (n = 14), control + testosterone (n = 4), Wobbler (n = 7), and Wobbler + testosterone (n = 4) mice was collected, and serum levels of LH and FSH were measured by RIA with kits from the National Hormone and Pituitary Program, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (Bethesda, MD, USA) and Dr A. F. Parlow (National Hormone and Pituitary Program, Torrance, CA, USA). As previously described, the results were expressed in terms of RP3 rat LH and FSH standards because these systems recognize mouse proteins [29, 36]. Assay sensitivities: 0.10 ng mL−1 for LH and 1.2 ng mL−1 for FSH. Intra- and interassay coefficients of variation were 7.2% and 11.4% for LH and 8.0% and 13.2% for FSH, respectively [36].
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Immunohistochemistry and Immunofluorescence. At the end of the treatment period (60 days), 22 mice (control, n = 8;Wobbler, n = 8; Wobbler + testosterone, n = 6) were prepared for immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence analyses. Mice were anesthetized with a mixture of xylazine (Bayer, Argentina) (6 mg/kg) and ketamine (Holliday-Scott, Argentina) (75 mg/kg) and perfused intracardially with 0.9% NaCl followed by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA). The cervical spinal cord segments C2–C6 were dissected after laminectomy, postfixed for 2.5 h in 4% PFA and then immersed in 20% sucrose overnight for cryoprotection or in 70% ethanol for paraffin inclusion. Pituitary, adrenal gland, testis, and seminal vesicles were also collected to evaluate the effect of testosterone on endocrine glands and target tissues. Tissue sections obtained with the microtome (5 μm) or cryostat (30 μm) for immunohistochemistry, were first washed in 0.01 M phosphate buffer containing 0.14 M NaCl (PBS) and then immersed in H2O20.3% in methanol to block endogenous peroxidase. Following preincubation in 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) for 10 min at 37 °C, sections were incubated overnight with a primary antibody labeling motoneurons (choline acetyltransferase-ChAT) or astroglial cells (quiescent and reactive astrocytes: glial fibrillary acidic protein- GFAP) under conditions specified in Table 1. Sections were then washed, incubated with the secondary biotinylated antibody and processed according to the instructions of the ABC kit (Vector Labs, CA, USA). The peroxidase activity was revealed using diaminobenzidine tetrachloride (DAB, 0.25 mg/ml, SIGMA, St. Louis, MO) in 0.01% H2O2 for 7 min in the dark. After a final rinse in PBS, sections were dehydrated in ethanol and xylene, and covered with mounting media (Permount). For immunofluorescence, cryoprotected tissues were embedded in Tissue-Tek (OCT Compound, Miles Inc., USA) frozen over dry ice and sectioned (30 μm) in a cryostat at − 20 °C. Sections were washed in PBS, and subjected to antigen retrieval in a microwave during 10 min at 120 °C in 10 mM citrate buffer. After incubation in 3% BSA in PBS for 10 min at 37 °C, tissues were incubated with antibodies labeling 3- nitrotyrosine (3-NT) and microglia [Ionized calcium binding adaptor molecule 1(IBA1)] prepared in 3% BSA, 1% Triton X100 in PBS (Table 1). After further washes, sections were incubated with the 2nd antibody conjugated to Alexa 555 or Alexa488 (Table 1). Finally, sections were washed with PBS, dried at room temperature, and mounted with Fluoromont-G (Southern Biotech, Birmingham, Alabama, USA). Nonspecific labeling was identified in sections without the first antibody.Immunofluorescence was examined with an Olympus IX83 inverted microscope equipped with a disk-spinning unit (DSU, Olympus Corporation, Japan). Digital images were acquired using Cell Sens Dimensions software from Olympus and photographed with a Hamamatsu Orca Flash 4.0 monochromatic camera (Hamamatsu Photonics K.K, Japan). Quantitative analysis of immunoreactive cells was carried out every 6 sections along the cervical spinal cord (from C2 to C6 level) [32, 37, 38]. Digital images of DAB-stained sections were captured under the same light intensity and exposure time. Immunofluorescent images were analyzed using the Image J Software (NIH, MD, USA), while DAB immunoreaction was analyzed using Optimas Software (Bioscan Optimas 6.02, USA) [32, 37, 38]. We adjusted the exposure time to acquire fluorescent images below the saturation level for the highest immunofluorescence signal and this condition was kept throughout all samples. Measurements of 3-NT immunofluorescence intensity level in neuronal bodies of the ventral spinal cord were performed with maximum intensity using FiJi-ImageJ software (NIH, Bethesda, MD)[39]. The number of ChAT, 3-NT, GFAP, or IBA1+ cells was quantified in the region of interest of the grey matter (ventral horn) and white matter (ventrolateral funiculus and corticospinal tract). Results were expressed as the number of immunoreactive cells per unit area. We also determined the microglia morphological phenotype according to Torres Platas et al. [40]. Ramified microglia showed small body and several highly ramified processes. Primed microglia showed an ellipsoid soma with fewer ramified processes. The reactive microglia contained a round soma with some ramifications, whereas amoeboid microglia lacked processes. Phenotype classification was performed using “Z-stack” analysis employing an EZ-C1 3.70 free-viewer. Identification of the ramified, primed, reactive, and amoeboid forms was carried out in at least 10 Z-stack images measuring 1-μm thick. Results were expressed as % cells in each category.We analyzed the presence of 3-NT by immunofluorescence microscopy.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Quantitative Analysis of Vacuolated Neurons. Five-micrometer sections were stained with cresyl violet to visualize neurons exhibiting a vacuolated cytoplasm. Sections were observed with a Zeiss Axiophot microscope, and the number of vacuolated cells in 10 sections per animal (n = 5–7 animals per group) was expressed per unit area (mm2) of ventral horn using Bioscan Optimas 6.02 software. We also quantified the total number of cresyl violet stained neurons, in order to express the % vacuolated neurons/unit area of ventral horn.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Histochemistry for Nitric Oxide Synthase/NADPH Diaphorase. For measuring NADPH diaphorase (NADPH-d) activity, we employed a slight modification of the Vincent and Kimura method [41]. Thirty-micrometer sections of the cervical spinal cord previously fixed in 4% PFA and cryoprotected in 20% sucrose, were washed and incubated in 0.1MTris–HCl buffer pH 7.4 containing 0.3% Triton X-100, 0.2-mg/ml tetrazolium blue, 2.7-mg/ml malic acid, and 1-mg/ml β-NADPH (all Sigma reagents) in the dark for 90 min at 37 °C. After several washed in PBS, sections were briefly dehydrated in ethanol, xylene, and mounted with Permount. NADPHd active cells were counted in the ventral horn, ventrolateral funiculus, and corticospinal tract using Optimas Bioscan 6.02 software, corresponding to 12–15 sections per animal (n = 5–7 animals per group).
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text:
Real Time PCR. For RNA extraction, 39 mice (control = 13, Wobbler = 12, Wobbler + testosterone = 14) were euthanized by decapitation, and cervical spinal cords were obtained under RNAsefree conditions and frozen over dry ice and stored at − 80 °C until used. Tissues were homogenized with a Politron homogenizer and RNA extracted with Trizol (Life Technologies- Invitrogen, CA, USA). Concentration and purity of RNA was determined by measuring the OD at 260 and 280 nm. After ethanol precipitation, samples were diluted with distilled water to a concentration of 1 μg/μL. Total RNA was treated with DNAse 1 (Promega), and cDNA was synthesized in the samples from 2 μg RNA by incubation with the enzyme reverse transcriptase M-MLV (Promega) during 60 min at 37 °C after treatment with an RNAse inhibitor. Cyclophilin b was used as the housekeeping gene in all the samples. CDNAs were amplified in a Step One Plus Real Time PCR Systems, employing 10 or 20-ng cDNA under optimized conditions consisting in 10 min at 95 °C, followed by 40 cycles at 95 °C during 0.15 s and 60 °C during 1 min. The relative gene expression was calculated by the 2−ΔΔctmethod [42], and results expressed as fold change compared to controls. Melting curves were performed to confirm the specificity of amplification and the absence of dimers. Primer concentration varied between 0.2 and 0.4 μM. Table 2 shows the sequences for primers used in qPCR experiments.

In order to elucidate the receptor type involved in the neuroprotective actions of testosterone, we measured the expression of AR, ERα, and Sigma-1 receptor by qPCR, whose respective ligands are testosterone (AR and Sigma-1 receptor) and estradiol (ERα), hypothetically formed through the aromatization of exogenous testosterone.
title: Neuroprotective Effects of Testosterone in Male Wobbler Mouse, a Model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

text: Induction, evaluation and treatment of EAE in C57BL/6 mice. Female WT C57BL/6 mice (Charles River Laboratories, Sulzfeld, Germany) were kept under pathogen-free conditions and had access to food and water ad libidum. All experiments were conducted according to the German law of animal protection and were approved by local authorities. To induce EAE C57BL/6 mice between 6 to 8 weeks of age were actively immunized using a peptide consisting of amino acids 35–55 of myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG35–55, EVGWYRSPFSRVVHLYRNGK; synthesized and HPLC purified by R. Volkmer, Charite´, Berlin, Germany). Mice were injected subcutaneously with 200 mg of MOG35–55 peptide emulsified with complete Freund’s adjuvant (CFA; Sigma-Aldrich, Mu¨nchen, Germany) containing Mycobacterium tuberculosis (5 mg/ml; Difco, Detroit, MI, USA). Control animals were immunized with an equivalent volume of CFA emulsion that did A b-Lactam Antibiotic in EAE not contain MOG35–55 peptide. Additionally, all mice were injected intraperitoneally with pertussis toxin (400 ng; List Biological Laboratories, Campell, CA, USA) at the time of immunization and 2 days later. Mice were evaluated on a daily basis for changes in body weight, overt signs of illness, and clinical signs of EAE by two blinded investigators using the following 10-point scoring system (Fig. 1, 5): 0, no neurological signs; 1, distal tail limpness; 2, full tail limpness; 3, beginning broad-based gait with mild ataxia; 4, severely broadbased gait and pronounced ataxia; 5, mild hind limb paraparesis; 6, severe hind limb paraparesis; 7, hind limb paraplegia; 8, tetraparesis; 9, tetraplegia, moribund; and 10, death attributable to EAE. Mean cumulative clinical scores were determined as the mean of the cumulative scores of all mice of a certain experimental group (Fig. 1B, 5B, Tab. 1). Days of disease onset and peak clinical score were determined from the time course of mean clinical scores of a certain experimental group (Tab. 1). Mice were treated in various combinations with ceftriaxone (200 mg/kg/d i.p.; Fresenius, Bad Homburg, Germany) and/or dihydrokainate (10 mg/kg/d i.p.; Sigma-Aldrich, Mu¨nchen, Germany) both dissolved in water as indicated in results.

Western blotting of whole mouse brain protein. Non-immunized WT C57BL/6 mice were treated with ceftriaxone (200 mg/kg/d i.p.) or an equal volume of saline, sacrificed after 5, 10 or 15 days of treatment and lysates from cortex, hippocampus, optic nerve and spinal cord were used for western blotting procedures. Brain tissue was washed with ice-cold PBS, resuspended in lysis buffer (PBS containing 1% Triton X-100 and protease inhibitor cocktail (Roche Diagnostics, Germany)) and solubilized by sonification on ice. Cell lysates were centrifuged and protein content in the clarified supernatant was measured using the Bradford reaction. Samples containing equal amounts of protein were subjected to 10% SDS-PAGE, followed by transfer to nitrocellulose membranes. Protein transfer was visualized by Ponceau S staining and membranes were then blocked with PBS containing 0.05% Tween 20 and 5% dry milk. The membranes were probed with rabbit anti-EAAT2 (1:50; Merck Chemicals, Darmstadt, Germany) directed against n-terminal amino acids 16– 31 of the transporter to assure detection of both EAAT2a and –b and rabbit anti b-actin (1:200; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Heidelberg, Germany) as protein loading control. The secondary antibody was HRP-conjugated donkey anti-rabbit (1:3000; Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK). The antibody reaction was detected by enhanced chemiluminescence reaction (ECL, Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK) (Fig. 2A). Specificity of the EAAT2 antibody binding was assessed by 5 hours incubation of the undiluted antibody with the immunogenic synthetic peptide corresponding to amino acids 16–31 of rat EAAT2 (Merck Chemicals, Darmstadt, Germany) previous to western blotting (Fig. 2B).

To assess the regulation of EAAT2 protein expression levels in the CNS in response to ceftriaxone treatment, non-immunized C57BL/6 mice were injected daily with ceftriaxone (200 mg/ kg/d), sacrificed after 5, 10 or 15 days of treatment, and the EAAT2 protein content of several brain areas was assessed by western blot.

Radioactive glutamate uptake in rat primary mixed glia cell cultures. Uptake of radioactive L-glutamate was measured in the rat primary mixed glial cell culture after 5 days of incubation in standard-media containing various ceftriaxone concentrations (Fig. 3). Subsequent determination of uptake was performed using solutions composed of (in mM) 140 NaCl, 4 KCl, 2 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 5 HEPES, pH 7.4 supplemented with 60 mM L-glutamate and 6 nML-[3H]glutamate (Amersham, Freiburg, Germany) according to the known Km value of EAAT2 for glutamate [19] as well as ceftriaxone at the respective concentration. To determine the fraction of total glial uptake mediated by EAAT2, the EAAT2- specific uptake inhibitor dihydrokainate (1 mM; Sigma-Aldrich, Mu¨nchen, Germany) was added. To determine the sodiumdependence of the uptake, sodium-free solutions were prepared by substituting sodium with N-methyl-D-glucamine (NMDG). L- [3H]glutamate uptake was terminated after 5 min of incubation by 3 times washing with glutamate-free solution, cells were suspended in 0.5% SDS and subjected to scintillation counting after lysis. Uptake of L-[3H]glutamate was linear for at least 10 min (data not shown) and pre-incubation with ceftriaxone did not change the average number of cells per well (data not shown).
tags_concatenated: C - rat primary mixed glia cells

text: Whole cell patch-clamp. Standard whole cell patch-clamp recordings were performed using an Axopatch 200B (Axon Instruments, Union City, CA) amplifier. Borosilicate pipettes were pulled with resistances of 1.0– 2.0 megohms. More than 80% of the series resistance was compensated by an analog procedure resulting in calculated voltage errors ,5 mV. Currents were filtered at 5 kHz and digitized with a sampling rate of 50 kHz using a Digidata (Axon Instruments) AD/DA converter. Transient transfection of tsA201 cells with pRCCMV hEAAT2 using the Ca3(PO4)2 technique was performed as previously described [51]. To identify cells with a high probability of expressing recombinant transporters, cells were co-transfected with a plasmid encoding the CD8 antigen, incubated 5 min before use with polystyrene microbeads precoated with anti-CD8 antibodies (Dynabeads M-450 CD 8, Dynal, Great Neck, NY, USA) and detected through a Nikon Eclipse TS100 microscope. The CD8/hEAAT2 cDNA ratio was adjusted to ensure that almost every cell with beads exhibited currents with characteristic properties (Fig. 4A). Cells were clamped to 0 mV for at least 2 s between 10 ms test sweeps to potentials between 2200 mV and 100 mV were applied. Current amplitudes were determined 2 ms after the c-peak. The composition of the standard solutions was as follows: extracellular (in mM) 140 NaCl, , 4 KCl, 2 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 5 HEPES, pH 7.4; intracellular (in mM) 115 KCl, 2 MgCl2, 5 EGTA, 10 HEPES, pH 7.4. Substrate-containing external solutions were made by adding 500 mM L-glutamate. Extracellular recording solutions contained either 1 mM or 0 mM ceftriaxone and previous to electrophysiological assessment, tsA201 cell transfected with hEAAT2 were incubated over-night in standard-medium containing either 1 mM or 0 mM ceftriaxone as indicated (Fig. 4B, C).

Assessment of T cell invasion into the CNS in vivo. Splenocytes of 2D2 TCR-transgenic mice [25] were plated at a densitiy of 16107/well on a 12 well plate and primed by incubation with MOG35–55 (20 mg/ml) on day 1 and 5 and IL-2 (500 IU/ml) on day 1 and 4. On day 3, supernatant medium was taken, analysed for INFc release using mouse-IFNc-ELISA according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Duoset, R&D Systems, Wiesbaden, Germany) to control for appropriate cytokine release (data not shown) and substituted by fresh medium. For T cell proliferation analysis, [methyl-3H]-thymidine (1.0 mCi/well; Amersham Biosciences, Buckinghamshire, UK) was added to stimulated splenocytes transferred to 96-well plates at a density of 56105 cells/well for 24 h on day 3 of in vitro culture. Afterwards, cells were harvested and [methyl-3H]-thymidine incorporation was measured using a liquid scintillation counter (Packard BioScience, Meriden, USA) to control for appropriate proliferation (data not shown). After 5 days of in vitro culture 2D2 splenocytes were collected, washed three times with PBS and 36106 cells/mice were adoptively transferred via intravenous injection into recipient C57BL/6 mice pre-treated for 5 days with and without ceftriaxone (200 mg/kg i.p.). 4 days after the adoptive transfer, during which no ceftriaxone treatment was performed, brains of recipient mice were removed and the fraction of CNS-invasive cells was analysed via flow cytometry (Fig. 6) of 3 to 4 pooled brains per experimental group. Absolute numbers of CD4 + T cell per brain were calculated from the absolute number of isolated leukocytes per brain and the fraction of CD4 + T cells acquired during FACS analysis.

Immunophenotyping. For flow cytometric analysis (Fig. 7A, B) of lymphocytes isolated from spleen of treated and untreated immunized mice at the disease maximum, single cell suspensions were prepared as described above. Flow cytometry was performed using standard methods. For analysis of T cell subtype distribution cells were stained for 30 minutes with appropriate antibodies or isotype controls (all by BD Bioscience): rat anti-mouse CD4-PerCP (No. 553052), rat anti-mouse CD8a-PE (No. 553033), rat antimouse CD44-FITC (No. 553133), rat anti-mouse CD62L-APC (No. 553152). Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) were analysed using the following antibodies (all by BD Bioscience): rat anti-mouse CD11b-PerCP (No. 350993), hamster anti-mouse CD11c-APC (No. 550261), mouse anti-mouse MCHII-FITC (Serotec, No. MCA1501F), rat anti-mouse CD86-FITC (No. 553691), hamster anti-mouse CD80-FITC (No. 553768), hamster anti-mouse CD40-FITC (No. 553723). All antibodies were titrated for optimal staining. Flow cytometry analysis was performed using a FACSCaliburH system (BD Biosciences, Heidelberg, Germany) and results were analyzed using CellQuest Pro (BD Bioscience, Heidelberg, Germany) and FlowJo (Treestar, USA) software.

T cell activation and antigen-recall assays. For antigen-recall experiments (Fig. 7C, D), 16106 splenocytes/ well from permanently and therapeutically ceftriaxonetreated and untreated MOG-immunized mice were cultured on 24-well plates with 10 mg/ml MOG35–55-peptide for 72 h. As control, splenocytes from the same mice were activated with anti- CD3/CD28 beads (Dynal Biotech, Oslo, Norway) at a ratio of 1:1 or left untreated. After 72 h, IFNc-levels were determined in the supernatants by mouse-IFNc-ELISA according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Duoset, R&D Systems, Wiesbaden, Germany). For T cell proliferation analysis (Fig. 8A), isolated CD4 + T cells from the spleen of non-immunized mice were stimulated with anti- CD3/CD28 beads (Dynal Biotech, Oslo, Norway) for 72 h, respectively, and 24 h before the end of incubation, [methyl-3H]- thymidine (1.0 mCi/well; Amersham Biosciences, Buckinghamshire, UK) was added. Cells were harvested and [methyl-3H]- thymidine incorporation was measured using a liquid scintillation counter (Packard BioScience, Meriden, USA). To asses the effect of ceftriaxone on antigen-presentation separated from T cell activation and proliferation (Fig. 8B, C), dendritic cells (DCs; 26106/well on 24 well plates) isolated from non-immunized mice were pulsed for 12 h with of MOG35–55 peptide (50 mg/ml) in the absence and presence of 100 and 500 mM ceftriaxone. Subsequently, DCs were washed and 16105 DCs per well were co-cultured for 3 days with 56105 syngeneic MOGreactive CD4 + T cells obtained from MOG-immunized mice at the disease maxium on 48-well plates (ratio of TC/DC=5:1). The supernatants were analyzed for IL2, IFNc, IL4, and IL17 production by ELISA according to the manufacturer’s protocol. All experiments were performed as triplicates.

Behavioral and Electrophysiological Analyses. Hindlimb and Forelimb Grip Strength. Animal weighing and all behavioral data collection began 1 week prior to transplantation, and was conducted twice weekly until end-stage. Hind- and forelimb muscle grip strengths were separately determined using a ‘‘Grip Strength Meter’’ (DFIS-2 Series Digital Force Gauge; Columbus Instruments, OH) [16]. Grip strength testing was performed by allowing the animals to grasp a thin bar attached to the force gauge. This was followed by pulling the animal away from the gauge until the hind- or forelimbs released the bar. This provides a value for the force of maximal grip strength. The force measurements were recorded in three separate trials, and the averages were used in analyses.
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Disease Onset. Hind- and forelimb disease onsets were assessed individually for each mouse by a 20.0% loss in hind- or forelimb grip strength relative to each animal’s own baseline grip strength level [16]
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Survival/Endstage Analysis. To determine disease endstage in a reliable and ethical fashion, endstage was defined by the inability of mice to right themselves within 30 seconds when placed on their sides.
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Compound Muscle Action Potential (CMAP) Recordings. Under anesthesia, phrenic nerve conduction studies were performed with stimulation (0.5 ms single stimulus; 1 Hz supramaximal pulses) at the neck via near nerve needle electrodes placed 0.5 cm apart along the phrenic nerve [19,20]. Recording was obtained via a surface strip along the costal margin, and CMAP amplitude was measured baseline to peak. Recordings across the nerve segment were made using an ADI Powerlab 8SP stimulator and BioAMP amplifier (AD Instruments: Colorado Springs, CO), followed by computer assisted data analysis (Scope 3.5.6; ADI). Distal motor latency of evoked potentials includes duration of nerve conduction between stimulating and recording electrodes plus time of synaptic transmission. CMAPs were collected at only a single time point (120 days of age).
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Quantification of Transplant Survival and Migration. HuNA (human nuclear antigen; Millipore; Temecula, CA; monoclonal; 1:400) was used to selectively identify transplantderived human cells (both hGRPs and hFs). Total numbers of HuNA + /DAPI + hGRPs (or hFs) were quantified in every 6th section throughout the extent of transplanted spinal cord at disease endstage [16]. Cell numbers from all sections were summed and multiplied by 6 to obtain the total number of surviving cells. Values were expressed as a percentage of the total number of cells transplanted. hFs were derived from fetal human dermis. Survival of hFs following transplantation was also assessed with HuNA.
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Quantification of Transplant Differentiation and Proliferation. The proportions of transplant-derived neurons (NeuN), astrocytes (pan-GFAP), cells of the oligodendrocyte lineage (Olig2), microglia (Iba1) and actively proliferating cells (Ki67) were expressed as a percentage of the total number of transplanted cells counted at specific locations along the cervical spinal cord relative to sites of injection [16]. In order to quantify double-labeling of HuNA with lineage-specific (pan-GFAP, Olig2, NeuN, Iba1) and proliferation (Ki67) markers, double-labeled sagittal sections containing the entire cervical enlargement, as well as additional rostral and caudal spinal cord tissue, were imaged at 206magnification using Zeiss AxioVision software. Images were analyzed in AxioVision at specific distances from the injection sites. For each animal (n= 6 mice), 6 different 206images were analyzed at each specific distance (3 in gray matter, 3 in white matter. In each image, every HuNA + cell with a matching DAPI + nucleus was assessed for co-expression of the lineage-specific marker, and these data were pooled from the 3 images to determine the value at each distance for each animal.
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Motor Neuron Survival. The cervical (C4–C6) spinal cord was serially sectioned transversely (30 mm) and stained with cresyl violet (Sigma-Aldrich) to quantify motor neuron numbers. Motor neurons were counted in every 7th section at 206magnification in order to avoid repetitive counting. Only motor neurons with a clearly identifiable nucleus and nucleolus, a cell soma over 100 mm2 and located within the ventral horn were counted at a 200-fold magnification, and the final counts were multiplied by seven to give an estimate of total cell numbers [16].
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text:
Western Analysis. Aliquots of homogenized cord samples from C5 were separately subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Blots were probed with antibody specific for GLT- 1 (1:5,000) [16]. Immunoreactivity was visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence, quantified densitometrically using Quantity One v4.0 software (BioRad; Hercules, CA), and normalized to actin.

Intraspinal levels of GLT1 were measured using Western blotting of whole cervical spinal cord segments at C5. hGRPs did not slow the loss of intraspinal GLT1 protein levels compared to hF controls
title: Human glial-restricted progenitor transplantation into cervical spinal cord of the SOD1 mouse model of ALS.

text: Body Weight. The weights of each mouse participating in this study were measured once every 5 days from 10 weeks old until sacrificed. The measured body weight of mouse per times was divided by its body weight at 10 weeks, and the mean of percentage of body weight was used as comparing the change of mouse body weight [24, 25].
title: All-Trans Retinoic Acid Exerts Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Like Tg (SOD1*G93A)1Gur Mice.

text: Motor Strength Testing. The motor function and strength were evaluated by the hanging wire test. In the hanging wire test, the mice were placed on a wired housing cage lid, and then swiftly inverted. The time from the lid inversion until the mouse released the lid with both hind limbs was measured.Mice were tested every 5 days starting from 10 weeks old. Each mouse performed 3 times to hold onto the inverted lid for an arbitrary maximum of 90 s, and the longest hanging time was used for the data analysis [24–27].
title: All-Trans Retinoic Acid Exerts Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Like Tg (SOD1*G93A)1Gur Mice.

text: Neurological Score Evaluation. Each mouse was scored for the neurological function 3 days/ time from the age of 10 weeks. The scoring criteria were based on the 0–4 rating system recommended by the ALS Therapy Development Institute (ALSTDI) [28]. The criteria used to assign each score were as follows: 0 score, the full extension of hind legs away from the lateral midline when the mouse is suspended by its tail, the mouse can hold this position for 2 s at a time when suspended two to three times; 1 score, the collapse or partial collapse of leg extension toward the lateral midline (weakness) or the trembling of hind legs during the tail suspension; 2 score, the toes curl under at least twice during a 12-in walk, or any part of foot is dragged along the cage bottom/table; 3 score, the rigid paralysis or the minimal joint movement, the foot is not being used for forwarding motion; 4 score, the mouse cannot right itself within 30 s from either side. Therefore, this study assessed the effects of ATRA treatment on the ALS disease progression based on changes in ALSTDI scores [24, 29, 30].
title: All-Trans Retinoic Acid Exerts Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Like Tg (SOD1*G93A)1Gur Mice.

text:
Western Blot Analysis. Animals prepared for Western blot analysis were euthanized by the cervical dislocation, and their spinal cord was rapidly extracted. Protein was isolated from the fresh lumbar medulla tissue in a lysis solution of RIPA lysate kit containing 1 mM PMSF (phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride) protease inhibitor (Solarbio, R0020, Beijing, China). The lysate was centrifuged for 5 min at 13,000×g at 4 °C. The protein concentration in the supernatants was determined with the BCA Protein Assay kit (Solarbio, PC0020, Beijing, China). Protein samples (20– 50 μg) were separated by the SDS-PAGE gel electrophoresis and transferred to the PVDF membranes (Millipore Corp. Bedford, MA, USA). Membranes were then blocked in the phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) containing 5%skim milk for 1 h at room temperature and incubated with primary antibodies, including anti-RARα (1:1000, Abcam), NNT (1:2000, Santa Cruz), TRX (1:2000, Abcam), SOD1 (1:1000, Proteintech), FUS/TLS (1:1000, Proteintech), TDP43 (1:1000, Proteintech), NGF (1:1000, Santa Cruz), NGFR (1:1000, Biotech) UBE3A (1:1500, Proteintech), GAPDH (1:1000, Solarbio), and β-actin (1:2000, Proteintech). The horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-secondary antibody of corresponding species was selected for each primary antibody. The chemical luminescence was evaluated using the BeyoECL Plus Kit (Beyotime, Shanghai, China), and the detailed procedures were the same as our previous study [24, 32]. The quantification was performed by measuring the band intensity with the ImageJ software (National Institute of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA).

The expression of RA signal (RARα and ALDH1A2) in the lumbar spinal cord was examined by western blot
title: All-Trans Retinoic Acid Exerts Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Like Tg (SOD1*G93A)1Gur Mice.

text: Immunohistochemistry and Image Analysis. For the immunohistochemistry, all mice were anesthetized and perfused 4% paraformaldehyde in 1× PBS (pH 7.5) at room temperature. The spinal cord was rapidly extracted and put into 4% paraformaldehyde buffer overnight, hatched in 20% sucrose-PBS buffer (pH 7.5), and embedded using the OCT compound. Then, 12 μm sectionswere successively cut in a Leica cryostat (Wetzlar, Germany) and pasted on the Superfrost Plus slides. In the processes of spinal immunohistochemical stain, sections were permeabilized using 0.2% Triton X-100 and blocked using 5% bovine serum albumin (Boster, China) after rehydrating in 1× PBS (pH 7.4), and incubating using the following primary antibodies: anti- NGFR, (1:200, R&D Biotech), NeuN, (1:250 Abcam), and GFAP (1:750 Abcam) at 4 °C overnight, and subsequently washed 5 times for each 5 min using 0.2% Tween 20 in 1× PBS. The secondary antibody used fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) donkey anti-goat (1:250, Abcam), and tetramethylrhodamine (TRITC) donkey anti-rabbit (1:200, Abcam) for 2 h at room temperature. Next, the sections were washed 5 times for each 5 min using 0.2% Tween 20 in 1× PBS buffer and incubated with DAPI (Boster, China) for 10 min. Finally, the sections were mounted with the antifade medium and observed on a Nikon E800 fluorescent microscope with a spot digital camera (Diagnostic Instruments, Sterling Heights, MI, USA). For the quantitative analysis, NeuN- and GFAP-positive cells were counted manually at least 100 neurons per slice per animal following an established protocol [33]. The relative fluorescence intensity of NGFR used optical density value calculated by the Image-Pro Plus (Media Cybernetics, Rockville, MD, USA), and the detailed protocols were the same with the description of our previous studies [23, 24, 32].
title: All-Trans Retinoic Acid Exerts Neuroprotective Effects in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis-Like Tg (SOD1*G93A)1Gur Mice.

text:
Facial motor neuron axotomy in rat pups. Rat pups were unilaterally axotomized at P14, treated once daily for 21 days with graded doses of CGP 3466A p.o. or s.c., killed on the last treatment day and motor neuron somata counted in Nissl stained sections of the facial nucleus. Data are means :t: SEM (n = 7-8) in percent of the difference in cell count between nonaxotomized and axotomized controls (left ordinate). Values at 0.0003mg/kg s.c. or 0.003mg/kg p.o. and above were significantly (p < 0.05) higher than those of
axotomized controls.

Transient ischemia/hypoxia: Rats were exposed to a period of hypoxia 24h after ligation of the left carotid artery and treated with graded doses of CGP 3466 p.o. or s.c. 1h after hypoxia and then daily for 6 days. They were sacrificed one day later and intact CAl
neurons were counted. Data are means :t: SEM (n = 6--9) in percent of the difference in cell count between nonischemic and ischemic controls (left ordinate). Values at 0.0001mg/kg s.c. or 0.0003mg/kg p.o. and above were significantly higher than those of ischemic controls.

MPTP-induced degeneration of nigral dopaminergic neurons: Mice were injected twice with 30mg/kg s.c.MPTP at an interval of 72h. Treatment with graded doses of CGP3466B was begun 48h thereafter and maintained twice daily for 18 days. The day after the
last treatment, the animals were sacrificed and TH immunopositive neurons counted in the substantia nigra pars compacta. Data are means :t: SEM (n = 8-11) in percent of the difference in cell count between controls and mice treated with MPTP alone (left
ordinate). Values at 0.014 and 0.14mg/kg p.o. and were significantly (p < 0.05) higher than those of the animals treated with MPTP only.

Nigral 6-0HDA lesions in rats (paw test): Rats were bilaterally lesioned with 3 ug 6OHDA intranigrally. Treatment with graded s.c. doses of CGP 3466B was begun 2h later and maintained twice daily for 2 weeks. After another 2 weeks washout , the animals were
subjected to the paw retraction test. Data are means :t: SEM (n = 6--7) of the time in s until they retracted the hindpaws from the holes in the test plate (right ordinate). Dotted lines indicate the mean values obtained from 6-0HDA-lesioned (lower) or sharn-lesioned
(upper) animals. The latencies obtained with 0.0014, 0.014 and 0.14mg/kg were significantly shorter (p < 0.05) than those of the 6-0HDA-lesioned controls.

Survival of pmn mice: Homozygous pmn mice were treated orally with graded doses of CGP 3466B every 2nd weekday (3 times per week) , beginning when the first symptoms were seen (P15-17) and maintained until the animals died. Data indicate mean survival in
days :t: SEM (n = 6--9), referring to the rightmost ordinate. The survival times of the animals treated with 3.9 and 39ug/kg were significantly longer than those of pmn controls.

Assessment of muscle function and number of motor units. Isometric contractions were elicited by stimulating the EDL motor nerve using square-wave pulses of 0.02 ms duration and supramaximal intensity via silver-wire electrodes. Contractions were elicited by trains of stimuli at frequencies of 20, 40 and 80 Hz. The half-relaxation time values were measured with the aid of a computer and appropriate software.We assessed the number of motor units in the EDL muscles by stimulating the motor nerve with stimuli of increasing intensity, resulting in stepwise increments in twitch tension because of successive recruitment of motor axons.

title: Treatment with arimoclomol, a coinducer of heat shock proteins, delays disease progression in ALS mice.

text: Fatigue test.EDL muscles were stimulated at 40 Hz for 250 ms every second, and contractions were recorded with a pen recorder (Lectromed Multitrace 2). The decrease in tension after 3 min of stimulation was measured, and the fatigue index was calculated as (initial tetanic tension – tetanic tension after 3 min stimulation) ÷ initial tetanic tension.
title: Treatment with arimoclomol, a coinducer of heat shock proteins, delays disease progression in ALS mice.

text: Motoneuron survival. After transcardiac perfusion with 4% paraformaldehyde, the lumbar region of the spinal cord was removed and 20-μm transverse sections were cut and stained with gallocyanin (a Nissl stain). Gallocyanin-stained motoneurons located within the sciatic motor pool, in which a nucleolus was clearly visible,were counted in each ventral horn on every third section between the L2 and L5 levels of the spinal cord. This method avoids the possibility of counting the same cell twice.
title: Treatment with arimoclomol, a coinducer of heat shock proteins, delays disease progression in ALS mice.

text: Immunocytochemistry. Sections of spinal cord were immunostained with antibodies to human SOD-1 (1:500; Sigma) or HSP-70 (1:100; Stressgen), using a previously described method13.
title: Treatment with arimoclomol, a coinducer of heat shock proteins, delays disease progression in ALS mice.

text:
Clinical measurements. The hind-paw extension reflex test was used to define the onset of disease and the loaded-grid test as a measure for the progression of disease.23,24 The extension of the hind limbs when mice are suspended in the air by the tails is diminished early during the course of their life span, long before motor neuron loss takes place.22 This test was performed five days a week by one investigator (GJG), who was blinded for experimental groups. The loaded grid test is a test of muscle strength, as mice have to grip a small loaded grid with a total weight of 40 g, and are then lifted by their tail. The length of time mice are able to hold on to the grid, with a maximum of 30 sec, is measured.24 The loaded grid test was performed twice a week by the same investigator (JdLvW). An impossibility to hold on to the loaded grid for more than 1 sec was considered a measure for progressed muscular weakness. For ethical reasons, the clinical endpoint was defined as the moment mice were no longer able to right
themselves within 2 seconds when laid on their back. After reaching the clinical endpoint, mice were sacrificed.
title: CGP 3466B has no effect on disease course of (G93A) mSOD1 transgenic mice.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and other motor neuron disorders : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology, Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Motor neuron count. The influence of CGP 3466B on the number of motor neurons in the spinal cord was evaluated in two mice from each group, at the age of 110 days, when onset of disease as defined by the hind-paw extension reflex test is usually present, but overt paralysis is not. The mice were anaesthetised with Nembutal (300mgkgx1) injected intra-peritoneally. After opening of the thorax, phosphate buffered saline (PBS) with heparin (20 IE/ml) was infused intra-cardially for 1min. Subsequently, mice were fixed with freshly prepared 4% paraformaldehyde. The spinal cord was dissected and post-fixed overnight in 4% PFA in 0.1M phosphate buffer (pH 7.3) at 4‡C. The spinal cord was cryo-protected with sucrose solution overnight at 4‡C. The lumbar segment of the spinal cord was fixed on a cork paper impregnated with M-1 embedding matrix (Sakura, Bayer). This was frozen in isopentane, which was cooled by liquid nitrogen to a temperature of x160‡C. For identification of motor neurons, every tenth transverse spinal cord section (10 mm) was incubated overnight with a polyclonal choline acetyl transferase (ChAT)-antibody (goat-anti-ChAT (Chemicon International, Temecula, CA, USA); diluted 1:200 in PBS containing 0.2% BSA and 0.1% NaN3 (PBS-BSA-Azide)). Sections were subsequently rinsed with 0.1M PBS, incubated with biotinylated secondary antibody (rabbit-anti-goat-antibody (Vector Laboratories Inc., Burlingame, CA, USA)(diluted 1:220 in PBS-BSA-Azide) for 1 h, and finally incubated with a horseradish- peroxidase conjugated Avidin-Biotinylated Complex (Vector Laboratories Inc., Burlingame, CA, USA) for 1 h. Motor neurons were visualised using DAB-Co-Ni 25 and the sections were counter-stained with Nuclear Fast Red.
title: CGP 3466B has no effect on disease course of (G93A) mSOD1 transgenic mice.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and other motor neuron disorders : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology, Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Survival. Animals were assessed twice daily (early morning and late afternoon) for morbidity and mortality by two independent observers who were blinded to the assigned treatment (RJF and KS). Motor performance and ability to feed was closely monitored and used to determine when to euthanize the mice. Animals were euthanized when they were unable to right themselves after being placed on their back for 30 s. Some deaths occurred overnight and were recorded the following morning. Body weights were recorded weekly on the same day and time.
title: Combined riluzole and sodium phenylbutyrate therapy in transgenic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Behavior analysis. Neuromuscular function was assessed using the Grip Strength apparatus (Columbus Instruments, Columbus, OH). This instrument measures the peak amount of force an animal applies in grasping specially designed pull-bar forelimb and hindlimb assemblies. Briefly, mice were held by the scruff of their back and drawn along in a straight line along the sensor assemblies to allow the mice to grasp the forelimb pull-bar assembly, recording the force applied by the forelimbs of the mouse in Newtons. In a continued sweep, the mouse was drawn along until the hindlimbs grasped and released the hindlimb assembly, again recording the force applied by the hindlimbs of the mouse. Forelimb and hindlimb strength were measured by the same investigator (SJD) three times and averaged during each weekly assessment. It is critically vital that a single investigator performs the grip strength measurements due to inter-rater differences in tensile strength.
title: Combined riluzole and sodium phenylbutyrate therapy in transgenic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Neuronal quantitation. Serial lumbar spinal cord tissue sections (n 20) from L3 L5 spinal cord segments were used for gross spinal cord areas and neuronal analysis. Gross areas of the spinal cord sections were quantified from each experimental cohort using NIH Image. From the same sections, the ventral horn was delineated by a line from the central canal laterally and circumscribing the belly of gray matter. Absolute neuronal counts of Nissl-positive neurons were performed in the ventral horns in the lumbar spinal cord. Only those neurons with nuclei were counted. All counts were performed with the experimenter (SJD) blinded to treatment conditions. Counts were performed using Image J (NIH) and manually verified and the data represent the average neuronal number from the sections used.
title: Combined riluzole and sodium phenylbutyrate therapy in transgenic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice.
journal: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis : official publication of the World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Motor Neuron Diseases

text: Cell death detection assay. MNs cocultured with wild-type or hSOD1 (G93A) ACs for 2 days were washed with PBS and then stained using the TMR Cell Death Detection kit (cat. no. 1684795; Roche) and 7AAD according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Dead cells were determined by 7AAD and TUNEL fluorescence. Healthy cells were detected by Hoechst 33342 fluorescence. See Supplemental digital content 1 (http://links.lww.com/ WNR/A405), for more detailed Materials and methods.
title: Methylcobalamin prevents mutant superoxide dismutase-1-induced motor neuron death in vitro.

text: Mouse phenotype monitoring and behavioral analysis. Mice were weighed every 3 days and their phenotype was monitored once a day. In order to observe themovement of the limbs, themicewere suspended by their tails, and themovement of the forelimbs and hind limbs was observed for 30 s. The mice were scored based on the appearance of a phenotype any point in the observation period. The scoring criteriawere: (1) no abnormality: 0 points; (2) physical disability: 1 point; (3) deflection to one side: 2 points and (4) limbs curled up: 3 points.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Grip strength test. The mouse was lightly placed on the center of the grip plate, prompting the animal to grasp the grip plate, and then gently pulled by the tail. Each animal was tested three times and the average value of the three results was taken as the evaluation value. After the start of the formal experiment, mice were tested once a week.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Grid test. The wire lid of a common cage was used to assess the limb grip strength. The mouse was placed in the center of the wire lid (21 cm×21 cm), which was then turned upside down for up to 90 s. The length of time the mouse held on to the wire was recorded.Micewere trained for 3 days before testing.The holding time of each mouse was measured twice, and the average value was taken as the result. Mice were tested once a week.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Climbing-pole test. The climbing-pole test was used to assess the movement and coordination of themouse. This employed a homemade wooden rod approximately 50 cm long and approximately 1 cm in diameter, wrapped with gauze to increase friction. The mouse was placed face down on the top of the vertical pole, and the descent time from the top of the pole to the bottom platform was recorded. Prior to testing, each mouse was trained for 3 consecutive days, twice a day, with a maximum cut-off of 15 s. The experimental procedure was repeated three times and the average descent time of each mouse was calculated as an evaluation value. This experiment was conducted once a week.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Balance beam. The balance beam task consists of placing the mouse on an elevated and narrow beam (1 cm wide and 50 cm long) and recording the time it takes for the mouse to cross the balance beam. Each mouse was tested three times. This experiment was conducted once a week.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Rotarod test. Rotarod performance was assessed using a rotarod test (Rotamex 4/8, Columbus Instruments International, Columbus, OH, USA). Mice were trained for 5 min on 3 consecutive days with the rotarod speed at 20 rpm, and testing was carried out the following 3 days. The speed of the rod was set to 30 rpm and increased by 1 rpm/s. Each mouse was subjected to three trials, and the average data for each group were plotted. This experiment was conducted once a week.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text: Novel object recognition test. The novel object recognition tests were conducted in an openfield arena (30×30×30 cm) constructed with polyvinyl chloride, plywood and acrylic, as previously described (61). The task included training and retention over two consecutive days. On day 1 of the training session, the animals explored two identical objects (black plastic cubes, 5×5×5 cm) for 5 min. On day 2 of recognition session, one of the objects was replaced by a gray plastic square pyramidwith a newshape and color (5×5×7 cm), and the animals were again acclimated to the area for 5 min. The field was decontaminated with 10% ethanol and a dry cloth between the tests. Exploratory behavior was defined as the mice sniffing or touching the objects with their nose and/or forepaws at a distance of less than 2 cm. Sitting or circling around the objects was not considered to be exploratory behavior. The exploratory behavior was manually evaluated using a video camera by an observer blinded to the test conditions. Total exploration time was defined as the total amount of time spent near the two objects. Cognitive function was measured using a recognition index, which was the exploration time involving either of the two objects (training session) or the novel object (retention session) compared with the total exploration time. This calculation was performed at the end of the experiment.
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text:
Western blot. Samples were lysed in lysis buffer (RIPA lysis buffer, protease inhibitor and phosphatase inhibitor in a ratio of 98:1:1) for 30 min and centrifuged at 13 500 g for 30 min at 4◦C. The supernatant was then carefully aspirated for western blotting. A BCA assay (BCA Protein Assay Kit, Ford Biopharmaceutical Co., Ltd)was performed to determine the protein concentration of each sample. After mixing with the loading buffer and boiling at 100◦C for 15 min, 20 μg of protein from each sample was separated by 8– 12% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE). Polyvinylidene fluoride membranes were used for protein transfer. The membrane was blocked with 5% skim milk in TBST for 1.5 h at room temperature. The membrane was then covered with a specific primary antibody and refrigerated at 4◦C overnight. After overnight incubation, blots were washed and incubated with secondary antibodies and were then incubated for 60 min at room temperature with TBST washing strips and imaged by a gel imaging system after soaking in ECL luminescence. Quantitative analysis of western blots was performed using Image J.

NeuN (B) and GFAP (C) were evaluated by western blot
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

text:
Immunofluorescence. Frozen sections were used for immunofluorescence. The slide was first sealed with 3% BSA for 30 min and then incubated overnight with primary antibody at 4◦C. The sections were incubated with second antibody combined with appropriate Alexa Fluor 488 or 594 at room temperature for 1 h and mounted with DAPI (1:1000, C1002, Beyotime).

immunofluorescence staining also showed that M337Vmutant TDP-43 protein caused a loss of NeuN-positive neurons and that TBN treatment prevented this loss
title: TBN improves motor function and prolongs survival in a TDP-43M337V mouse model of ALS.

Wobbler mice were administered dietary EPI-589
(5, 10mg/g in diet) or Edaravone (15mg/kg, i.p., daily) from
4 weeks of age after the motor symptom onset. Rotarod walking time and forelimb deformity were assessed once or twice
a week in a blinded manner as previously described (1,2).

At the end of treatment, animals were sacrificed for further histopathology and biomarker evaluation. The number of SMI-32 (motoneuron marker) and/or MG-160 (Golgi marker) immunoreactive neurons in the cervical cord ventral horn were counted(1). pNfH in plasma and 8-OHdG in urine were measured by ELISA. The ratio of spinal NAA to creatine (Cr) plus phosphocreatine (PCr) was analyzed by ex vivo 1H-MRS
